headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Third Quarter and Fiscal 2018 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, this conference is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd like to turn
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Third Quarter and Fiscal 2018 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, this conference is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Dennis Melton, Interim Head of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon to everyone. As the operator said, I'm Dennis Melton, F5's Interim Lead of Investor Relations. François Locoh-Donou, President and CEO of F5; and Frank Pelzer, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of th
componenttext:
Good afternoon to everyone. As the operator said, I'm Dennis Melton, F5's Interim Lead of Investor Relations. François Locoh-Donou, President and CEO of F5; and Frank Pelzer, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of the F5 Executive team are also on hand to answer questions following the prepared remarks.
If you have any questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6078 our d.melton@f5.com. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at www.f5.com. In addition, you can access an archived version of today's call from our website through October 24, 2018. You can also listen to a telephone replay at (866) 511-5155 or (203) 369-1955. 
In today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words, such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized on our quarterly release and described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call. 
I will now turn the call over to Frank.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dennis. My name is Frank Pelzer, and I'm very excited to discuss with you today, our fiscal 2018 Q3 results and Q4 outlook. Q3 marked a return to product revenue growth, as we had another quarter of solid execution and delivery of results. We
componenttext:
Thank you, Dennis. My name is Frank Pelzer, and I'm very excited to discuss with you today, our fiscal 2018 Q3 results and Q4 outlook. 
Q3 marked a return to product revenue growth, as we had another quarter of solid execution and delivery of results. We continue to see growing momentum with our software offerings, particularly solutions for multi-cloud architectures, and our services business delivered another quarter of strong revenue and profit. 
Third quarter revenue was $542 million, up 4.7% year-over-year and came in above the midpoint of our guided range of $535 million to $545 million.
GAAP EPS of $1.99 per share was above our guidance of $1.79 to $1.82 per share. This peak was largely driven by strength in revenue, expense discipline and the lower-than-expected effective tax rate. Non-GAAP EPS of $2.44 per share was also above our guidance of $2.36 to $2.39 per share. 
In Q3, product revenue was $239 million, up 1.6% year-over-year and accounted for 44% of total revenue. Software was approximately 15% of product revenue and grew 24% year-over-year. Systems revenue made up approximately 85% of product revenue and declined 1.5% year-over-year.
Services revenue was $303 million, up 7% year-over-year and represented 56% of total revenue. 
On a regional basis, Americas grew 3% year-over-year and represented 56% of total revenue. EMEA revenue grew 8% year-over-year and accounted for 24% of overall revenue. APAC revenue, which accounted for 15% of total, grew 8% year-over-year. And Japan at 4% of total revenue, grew 4% from year ago. 
Sales to enterprise customers represented 64% of total revenue during the quarter. Service providers accounted for 19% of total revenue, and government sales were 17%, including 7% from U.S. Federal. 
In Q3, we had 5 greater than 10% distributors. Ingram Micro, which accounted for approximately 17% of total revenue. Centex Corp. and Tech Data, which each accounted for approximately 11% and Arrow and Westcon each represented approximately 10% of revenue.
I will now discuss our operating results. 
GAAP gross margin in Q3 was 83.2%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 84.5% in line with our expectation. GAAP operating expenses of $299 million were at the lower end of our $297 million to $307 million guided range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $265 million. Our GAAP operating margin in Q3 was 27%, and non-GAAP operating margin was 36%. Our GAAP effective tax rate was 20.4%, lower-than-expected due to tax benefits associated with our stock-based compensation expense in the quarter. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 23.3%. Let's now discuss the balance sheet and other results.
We generated $182 million in cash flow from operations, up 12% year-over-year, which contributed to cash and investments totaling over $1.4 billion at quarter end. DSO at the end of the quarter was 49 days, flat with previous quarter. Capital expenditures for the quarter were approximately $20 million, driven by a build-out of our new headquarters and international facilities expansion. Inventory at the end of the quarter was approximately $31 million.
Deferred revenue increased 9% year-over-year to just over $1 billion, driven by continued high maintenance renewal rates. We ended the quarter with approximately 4,475 employees, up approximately 90 people from the prior quarter. 
In Q3, we purchased approximately 900,000 shares of our common stock at an average price of $166.22 per share for a total of $150 million. 
Now let me discuss our guidance for Q4. Based on strengthening pipeline and discussion with our sales organization, we see continuing momentum in the business as we close out the fiscal year. We expect to deliver another quarter of solid revenue growth with continued strength in product revenue. 
For the quarter, we are targeting revenue in the range of $555 million to $565 million. Today, we announced an initiative to further align spend with our transformation to a leading provider of multi-cloud application services. Specifically, we will be accelerating investment in our road map and market development efforts in the fastest growing areas of our business, cloud and security. As a result, we expect to take a restructuring charge in the range of $23 million to $25 million in Q4, that is reflected in our GAAP expense estimate.  We do not anticipate that this action will impact our Horizon 1 or Horizon 2 financial guidance that we laid out for you in March. 
In Q4, we expect GAAP gross margins of approximately 83%, including $5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. We anticipate non-GAAP gross margins of approximately 84.5%. We estimate GAAP operating expenses of $317 million to $329 million, including approximately $34 million of stock-based compensation expense, $23 million to $25 million in restructuring expense, and $0.8 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. We expect our GAAP effective tax rate of approximately 25% for the fourth quarter and the non-GAAP effective tax rate at or around 24%. 
Our Q4 GAAP earnings target is $1.77 to $1.88 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $2.61 to $2.64 per share. 
On a final topic, I'm happy to report that my first few months as F5 CFO have gone very smoothly. I've had the opportunity to work with all areas and levels in the business and have been very impressed by the high quality and depth of knowledge of all F5 employees, particularly our world-class finance and accounting team.
I would like to thank, everyone for their warm acceptance of me to the organization and their tireless efforts in building a fantastic business. 
With that, I will turn the call over to François.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank, and good afternoon, everyone. During the third quarter, we saw continued momentum across the business with product revenue returning to growth. Software revenue continues to expand driven by deployments in public and private cloud, as
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank, and good afternoon, everyone. 
During the third quarter, we saw continued momentum across the business with product revenue returning to growth. Software revenue continues to expand driven by deployments in public and private cloud, as our customers increasingly look to support and protect their applications across multi-cloud environment. We also saw strong demand for our security solutions, protecting enterprise customers that gave application-based threats. 
Our software revenue continues to expand, growing 24% year-over-year. The pace of ELA and BEA subscription software deals accelerated in Q3, as customers continued to embrace flexible consumption models, a trend we think will be important in driving adoption of our new cloud offerings, including our recently introduced BIG-IP Cloud Edition.
While cloud edition was just released to market at the end of May, we are already seeing strong interest and pipeline across the theaters. The early feedback from customers, who purchased the product in Q3, confirms our view that right sized application services for every app opens up a large set of used cases that were not previously well addressed by existing software ADC offerings. We expect momentum for Cloud Edition to continue to build and that it will be a meaningful driver of software growth in FY '19 and beyond.
In addition, we are seeing our customers increasingly choose to deploy a blend of both iSeries system along with software in multi-cloud environment. Customers continue to utilize F5 security, application services and orchestration to seamlessly manage workloads across these hybrid environments. 
Our services business had another solid quarter with revenue up 7% year-over-year and deferred revenue of $1 billion. This team provides unparalleled customer support, creating a significant differentiator and driving customer satisfaction. The value of our services capabilities will only grow, as the complexities associated with multi-cloud deployments become more prominent with our customers. 
We've shown strong execution during the third quarter for software solutions across all deployment environments with strength in public cloud, both in bring your license and utility-based consumption. We also saw a continued sequential growth for enterprise license agreements and subscription offerings. These offerings provide flexibility in procuring and deploying our virtual edition, leading to software expansion in-service provider enterprise accounts.
For instance, our ability to structure and ELA at a large U.S. financial services company help create a high-capacity DNS infrastructure. The policy-based DNS functionality provides resiliency against outrages across regional hubs. The deployment works across the 3 major clouds, allowing the customer to choose the right cloud provider for the task at hand. This CLA is part of multi-cloud software infrastructure and the customer continues to buy hardware systems to support a hybrid environment.
The traction we are seeing in software is augmented with the early success of BIG-IP Cloud Edition, which we officially launched on May 31. As a reminder, this release improved per app visibility, analytics and auto scale capabilities. The solution provides app owners a virtual application delivery controller that can apply and automate policy when developing, deploying and securing applications across public and private clouds. 
A large online services company in Asia purchased Cloud Edition to automate application deployment and shorten scale out time. Utilizing BIG-IP functionality paired with Cloud Edition, the customer was able to auto scale instances at the app level with analytics and seamless interoperability with other F5 solutions. 
Application protection continues to be a driver of security solutions with good momentum in our WAF offerings. A leading independent research firm identified F5 as a WAF leader with multiple consumption models, including a traditional application security manager, Advanced web application firewall and Silverline managed service. In the first full quarter of sale, advanced graph showing strong adoption from both new and existing customers. The operational use of configuration and deployment is attracting new stand-alone security buyers. A great example of this momentum in security is a competitive win at the European web hosting company, driven by our Advanced Web Application Firewall.
The customer deployed advanced WAF to protect their website portals and safeguard their brand reputation from application-level compromise by sophisticated Layer 7 DDoS attacks. 
The sales team participated in a competitive evaluation and demonstrated protection from bot-based attacks and superior behavior-based protection to catch subtle application layer DDoS attempts.
Highlighting our stated objective of offering stand-alone security products to a security buyer. Today, we are introducing F5 SSL Orchestrator. This dedicated security solution allows ease of deployment and configuration for enterprise customers that demand orchestration with high performance subscription, encryption and steering of SSL traffic. This product gives customers a security appliance, offering dynamic service across the security infrastructure. 
Consistent with our approach presented in our Analyst and Investor Meeting in March, we will continue to expand our stand-alone security portfolio. And today, we also announced the availability of F5 Access Manager. 
Core enhancements include protection of sensitive data with adaptive authentication, while providing access for authorized users, devices and APIs, guarding against pervasive threads, such as man-in-the-middle attacks. Access Manager enables organization to bridge on-prem app functionality to the cloud, effectively integrating with identity of the service solutions to support evolving, heterogeneous environments.
As we outlined over the past year, we are evolving to a multi-cloud application services company that will reach every app anywhere. With this in mind, we are realigning resources to better position F5 for 2019 and beyond. 
Today, we are taking steps to notify some employees that their roles are under consideration or will be eliminated in order to accelerate or hiring in geographic sales expansion, new sales go-to-market motions, multi-cloud software development and digital transformation initiatives. 
Our objective with these decisions is to further align our workforce with a long-term strategy and accelerate the transformation that we outlined in our Analyst and Investor Meeting earlier this year.
The long-term vision set forth is seeing significant traction with continued momentum in software and security sales. Customers continue to view our solutions as mission-critical in hybrid environment and they deploy incremental workloads dynamically, both on-premise and in cloud environment. The expansion of our software asset portfolio and stand-alone security products positions us as the leader in multi-cloud application services.
Before moving on to the question-and-answer session, I wanted to highlight 3 key additions to the leadership team. First, I am excited to announce that Chad Whalen has been promoted to Executive Vice President of Worldwide Sales. Chad joined F5 18 months ago, and has built up our cloud sales team, while significantly deepening our partnerships with Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services. Chad also bought to F5 a depth of experience that spans complex, large enterprises to fast-moving startups. His past leadership roles included Fortunate, Worldwide Package, Jasper and Sienna. Chad brings a combination of cloud, security, IoT and service provider expertise that we will leverage in our transformation to become a multi-cloud application services leader.
We were also pleased to announce on July 11, that Mary Gartner joined the F5 team as our new Chief Information Security Officer. Mary is a seasoned security leader with extensive experience in the health and finance sectors, where the protection of highly sensitive customer data and compliance with stringent regulations are business-critical issues. 
Prior to F5, Mary has held security leadership roles at Seattle Children's Hospital, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center and kept information and networks safe at Port of Seattle and Washington Mutual, JP Morgan Chase. 
Another important addition to our leadership team is James who joined this month as General Manager for our Service Provider Business. James comes to us with 14 years of where he held multiple leadership roles supporting the design and operation of their network architecture, including his most recent role as Vice President of Network Virtualization.
His hands-on insight into the challenges and opportunities service providers phase, as they rollout 5G, SSL and IoT services will be invaluable to F5 as we expanding our reach and role in these environments. 
I would like to welcome Chad, Mary and James to their roles on the F5 leadership team. 
As always, I would like to thank the entire time F5 team and our partners for their efforts during the third quarter. 
With that, we will now hand the call over for Q&A.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Samik from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Samik from JPMorgan.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to start off with a question on the restructuring that you announced today. How should I think about the payback on that kind of restructuring. Is it sort of the invention here is to sort of improve margins on the systems product? Or how sha
componenttext: I just wanted to start off with a question on the restructuring that you announced today. How should I think about the payback on that kind of restructuring. Is it sort of the invention here is to sort of improve margins on the systems product? Or how shall I think about impact on the financials longer-term?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Samik. Well, the first thing I would say about the restructuring is that, I genuinely don't like having to make these decisions, because ideally and philosophically, we would like to embark every employee that's been part of the F5 into this ex
componenttext: Thank you, Samik. Well, the first thing I would say about the restructuring is that, I genuinely don't like having to make these decisions, because ideally and philosophically, we would like to embark every employee that's been part of the F5 into this exciting future that we're building with this company. And our Executive team has taken into immense consideration onto this because we know that we are making decision that impact the lives of many of our colleagues and friends. That being said, we are very focused on the transformation of F5 into a multi-cloud application services leader. And as a result, there is legacy spend that we have that is less relevant to the future than it has been for the past. And we are shifting our focus to the growth areas of F5. And specifically, we are intensifying our investments into software and multi-cloud technologies, in new go-to-market motion and also in building the necessary digital infrastructure that enables those go-to-market motions. And so today's restructuring is really not about cost cutting, it really is about real realignment of resources towards these areas and accelerating the execution of our strategy. In terms of how you should think about this action as it relates to long-term financial model. It's all very consistent with what we shared at our Analyst and Investor Meeting in March, and so this action has no implied change in our Horizon 1 and Horizon 2 guidance, so this is FY '19 and also '21, '22.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. And just a follow up, you mentioned you're seeing good traction on your stand-alone security product. Can you might be sharing in terms of customer count on anything like that so that we can track your progress on that front? And also are
componenttext: Got it, got it. And just a follow up, you mentioned you're seeing good traction on your stand-alone security product. Can you might be sharing in terms of customer count on anything like that so that we can track your progress on that front? And also are your latest thoughts that you can sort of pursue that opportunity organically, or are you open to looking at certain acquisitions  on acquisitions to bolster your on that front?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Samik, I with the latter part of your question. In terms of acquisitions, I think we've touched on this before. I've said that, I consider acquisitions to be potential tool in the execution of our strategy as a technology company. If and when we find inve
componenttext: Samik, I with the latter part of your question. In terms of acquisitions, I think we've touched on this before. I've said that, I consider acquisitions to be potential tool in the execution of our strategy as a technology company. If and when we find investment opportunity that makes sense, we will execute on that. And the key for me is that we'll continue to be disciplined in our investments, whether they be investments in organic innovation or potential investments in inorganic innovation in the future that we think is a very disciplined approach to both. And that's what you're seeing in our actions today. In terms of the tractions that we're getting with our new stand-alone security offerings, we don't disclose customer accounts, but I can tell you that the new stand-alone security solutions that we have announced, we have already won number of customers in those, including a number of customers that are net new customers to F5. And the thing that for me is a significant sign of traction we are getting there is number of deals we are willing with our SSL orchestration solutions or our advanced WAF solutions. We are not competing with any ADC vendors. We really are only competing with traditional or next-generation security vendors. And our win rate is very strong. A good example of that is, if you take our SSL Orchestration solution, we just released, it really is a use case that is absolutely, critical to the security infrastructure, largely because most of the traffic now is encrypted. So the traditional security appliances are not very efficient at doing this encryption, decryption work in addition to security service they have to offer. And so, in this case, actually, F5's hardware -- security hardware is extremely efficient in encryption and decryption and we marry that with an intelligent policy-based training of security services. And that allows us to provide a service chain across the full security stack, and really nobody else can do that. So that is a great use case for how security solutions are outperforming. And it is absolutely, in line with our strategy to be the leader in application security.

componenttext: Sammy, I don't think we can give you the tax rate specifically. What I think, we can -- I think, share with you is, 2 things. One is, you continue to see growth in our software, essentially, in line with what we shared at the Investor meeting that software would grow in the mid-20s for the year. And we're confident this is essentially what we're going to land. And that's true across both our software growth in ADC and our software growth in security. I mean that has been the consistent trend over the number of quarters. The other thing we can share with you is, a large number of deals, even in security, I would say, a growing percentage of our business even in ADC, sorry, is actually driven by security use cases. So we don't break down -- we don't quantify that, but I'd say the traction in security is growing both in our ADC business as well as in our stand-alone security business.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then at the Analyst Day, there were some comments alluding to the other service product and the business model shift, et cetera. And I was hoping if you kind of give us a little bit of an update on that and may be any potential milestones or m
componenttext: Got it. And then at the Analyst Day, there were some comments alluding to the other service product and the business model shift, et cetera. And I was hoping if you kind of give us a little bit of an update on that and may be any potential milestones or maybe just like a change of mind or anything like that, can you just give us some color on that?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we -- Sammy, we offer today a managed service where we essentially redirect traffic from some of our customers to sporting centers that are largely in data center. And we perform a number of services in these clouding centers and that shows Silver
componenttext: Yes, so we -- Sammy, we offer today a managed service where we essentially redirect traffic from some of our customers to sporting centers that are largely in data center. And we perform a number of services in these clouding centers and that shows Silverline and it continues to go with other number of customers again in the quarter. In addition to that, we did say that in 2019, we would be bringing to market a solution called F5 as a Service, which is a -- it's a complete self-serve model that will be hosted in a public cloud, and would address all of the Dev Ops that want to go through a pure public file by emotion. We remain on track for that solution in 2019. We haven't announced the bid yet and we'll get closer to delivering on that.

componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just give us some qualified sizing around the growth rate in the security business? I know you don't want to break out the dollar value of it, but it would be helpful if you could at least talk about roughly what the rate of c
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just give us some qualified sizing around the growth rate in the security business? I know you don't want to break out the dollar value of it, but it would be helpful if you could at least talk about roughly what the rate of change in that business is? And then the second, if you could talk a little bit about what portion of your business is coming from SaaS or cloud-related footprint that would be helpful as well?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Alex, thank you. I'm going to disappoint you on both counts. Because I can't give you numerical. And it's not just that we want, but I'm going to start with security. In security, our business is both some stand-alone security use cases as well as securit
componenttext: Alex, thank you. I'm going to disappoint you on both counts. Because I can't give you numerical. And it's not just that we want, but I'm going to start with security. In security, our business is both some stand-alone security use cases as well as security-driven use cases in our ADC business. And sometimes breaking that up is actually quite subjective on our part. And this is one of the reasons that we don't disclose that information. I can on the other hand, share with you that security as a whole is a, one of the faster growing areas of our business. So it is growing faster than the aggregate revenue, if you will. As it relates to public cloud, again, we don't -- today, we may in the future. But we don't today, purely break out public cloud revenues. Public cloud is actually the fastest-growing part of our business. And we continue to drive customers to public clouds both by their license and sharing public cloud or buying into our systems on the utility basis. I'm sure that we're now billing millions of hours per quarter on all the major public clouds. And our cloud addition, we just released, actually, we expect to accelerate that, because it makes it easy for customers to bar some of their applications into public cloud, leveraging our auto scale capability. So that's where we see significant acceleration of our software solutions in the future. But I just can't quantify it further yet.

componenttext: No, there is no reason. We didn't mention, Alex. As we kind of predicted last quarter, we saw growing number of 7-figure software deals. And these are typically ELAs, enterprise license agreements. And we're seeing -- we only released these offerings about 9 months ago. And sequentially, every quarter over the last 3 quarters, we have seen the traction in pipeline with this consumption models going with our customers. And this quarter, we had a record number of such deals on software and on these enterprise license agreements. They are particularly important to us, because we can land customers on these deals and over time expand them and add to their initial subscription. So generally, pretty excited about what's happening with the large million-dollars-plus software deals that we are seeing.

componenttext: I wanted to -- I guess, I want to ask kind of a question about the progress of software again, but the real question I have is, when you guys think you might release some KPIs, help us quantify those. But that deferred revenue suggests there's not a whole lot of movement in the direction of software yet from the point of view of the overall revenue. So I'm just curious, is that true? Or is there a bunch of some more software deferred revenue in there than we think? And if you could see the breakdown, we'd see more progress.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. Raj, it's Frank. Let me take that one. So on the KPI question, I would say, as the business becomes more material, we'll consider certain KPIs that you can continue to track. At this point, we're talking about growth rates that we've experienced in
componenttext: Sure. Raj, it's Frank. Let me take that one. So on the KPI question, I would say, as the business becomes more material, we'll consider certain KPIs that you can continue to track. At this point, we're talking about growth rates that we've experienced in the business, particularly on the software side as an indication of the strength that we're seeing in that business. I think on your second question, on deferred revenue. It's actually up and close to 7%., 1.7% quarter-over-quarter, but 7% year-over-year. And we talked about that really the -- still the continued strength that we've seen in the maintenance. On the ELA side, and those are just a smaller portion of our total revenue. So it really doesn't have a major move yet in the deferred revenue piece.

componenttextpreview: Jason, let me start with the latter part first. This is the first year of us offering ELAs and subscriptions. And so no doubt there is an element of learning as we go through the first deals and kind of readjust, as we learn more and also as the volume of
componenttext: Jason, let me start with the latter part first. This is the first year of us offering ELAs and subscriptions. And so no doubt there is an element of learning as we go through the first deals and kind of readjust, as we learn more and also as the volume of these deals continues to increase. That being said, there was not a particular challenge upon pricing that we picked up in those deals. In fact, if anything, if you just look at discounting levels, we think the discounting levels in these types of deals are less than in traditional perpetual software deals. So we're pretty encouraged by the early trends around what we're seeing in terms of customer option. So there is not a challenge specifically with ELA or subscription deals.

componenttext: Okay. I guess -- what I was talking about what I meant by challenges is, we just heard that in some of the -- there were some transactions, where customers just pushed back on the pricing. So we thought it was too expensive, not consistent with what you said that there is not as much discounting. So we may be just picked up a couple of isolated instances. But it sounds like you are feeling good about that learning process and adjusting as necessary?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're feeling very good about it, Jason. There's always an element, of course, of negotiation with our customers. But we're feeling very good about the pricing, but also the consumption model. Our ELAs our unique that we allow customers to consume an
componenttext: Yes, we're feeling very good about it, Jason. There's always an element, of course, of negotiation with our customers. But we're feeling very good about the pricing, but also the consumption model. Our ELAs our unique that we allow customers to consume and add sort of consumption or throughput to their licenses during a period of time and then we true it after that. And once our customers really understand the consumption model that we're giving in these ELAs, they realize there is tremendous value using these ELAs and the adoption is pretty strong. So we're not -- if your question is, are we losing ELA deals because of pricing? The answer is absolutely, no.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to first, ask on the competitive dynamics. We didn't hear too much about that outside of essentially the stand-alone security space. Can you just give us an update on the landscape there as it relates to the last question regarding pricing?
componenttext: I just wanted to first, ask on the competitive dynamics. We didn't hear too much about that outside of essentially the stand-alone security space. Can you just give us an update on the landscape there as it relates to the last question regarding pricing? And especially, as it relates to some of the private vendors like CloudFlare and the recent announcement from Cisco and AV Networks?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James. So on the competitive landscape, we really like where things are going in the virtual ADC space. In particular, we're very happy with the traction that we've gotten with the Cloud Edition. It's just been in the market for 1 month. We alr
componenttext: Thank you, James. So on the competitive landscape, we really like where things are going in the virtual ADC space. In particular, we're very happy with the traction that we've gotten with the Cloud Edition. It's just been in the market for 1 month. We already have a substantial number of wins. And what's happening essentially, James, is we are offering things that have not been available in the market before. For the first time, we are enabling application teams to self service on their ADC, which is opening up new use cases. We also for the first time enabling teams to autoscale our solutions. So for the applications that are that's a very important capability. One of the companies, I mentioned in the script is the online services company in Asia. They really purchase cloud edition because they have naturally adverse to traffic. They don't have -- we have a sort of seasonal demand to their solutions. And so our ability to the capabilities and for them to really focus on what they're using is absolutely, critical. And all of that at the lower cost of ownership than in traditional VE. And so customers have not been able to get that from a vendor that has both the depth of features that we have and the world-class support that F5 brings to the table. And we see that as a substantial change in the ADC market. So we're very positive on our competitive position. And as I said before, in terms of ELA and subscription deals, we're doing well there, and we are not seeing a significant challenge from any other consumption models, you mentioned.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's very helpful color, François. One just last one from me, on the new F5 Access Manager, correct me if I'm wrong. You are partnering with leading provider that's cloud-based that essentially F5 was doing a on-premise environment and the part
componenttext: Got it. That's very helpful color, François. One just last one from me, on the new F5 Access Manager, correct me if I'm wrong. You are partnering with leading provider that's cloud-based that essentially F5 was doing a on-premise environment and the partner was doing the on-premise. Is this new product just integrating them more, or did you come out with your own off premise solution in this new release?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: This new release, James, is really targeted at customers that want to deploy on-prem or want to deprive across multi-cloud. And so it allows customers to essentially augment their capacity from on-prem to a private cloud or a multi-cloud in a seamless way
componenttext: This new release, James, is really targeted at customers that want to deploy on-prem or want to deprive across multi-cloud. And so it allows customers to essentially augment their capacity from on-prem to a private cloud or a multi-cloud in a seamless way. And really for them to auto scale the capability as they need. So it's not effecting a particular partner. It's more that we are really truly obsessed with what our customers want to do next. And we're delivering and innovation innovate that they want to consume the technology that they have been asking for. And in fact, in some cases, because they didn't have that solution from F5, they were looking at potentially other solutions either from startups or open-source players. And we're now seeing that you're intercepting some of these proof-of-concept and having significant win rate, because ultimately they want the solution from vendor that they trust and that has that capability to support them across multiple environments.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Catharine. So I'll speak a little bit short-term and longer term. In the short run, we continue to see a great traction with security firewall solutions, carrier-grade firewall solutions especially in the service provider market, because the in
componenttext: Thank you, Catharine. So I'll speak a little bit short-term and longer term. In the short run, we continue to see a great traction with security firewall solutions, carrier-grade firewall solutions especially in the service provider market, because the increase in traffic -- in mobile traffic, in particular, requires the scalability that our hardware specifically VIPRION solutions provide. So that's going to continue to grow and there are number of new use cases that are immediately short-term that are also driving demand for hardware, things like IoT with the high transactional type application drive significant demand for our hardware in the carriers pay us. If we take a more of a longer term perspective, number of carriers are looking to virtualize their infrastructure and the more they moved to virtualization, the more they need solutions for A, traffic management and B, security. Those 2 challenges become more and more as they virtualize their environment. And F5 is a leading player in both areas. And so we are taking really more deliberate steps and more strategic investment in these areas as evidenced by bringing on board James figure and some of the announcements we have made about a lot we are doing in the NFB space really to make sure that we are aligned with these 5G architectures, which is virtualize architectures, because our customers are asking for more format wide as a partner as they evolve their architectures.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: No, that's a great nuance. We had a necessary orchestrator solution recently. But it  -- there are 2 things with it. One is, it requires a significant level of -- if you want professional service or customization from F5 to make the solution work in a spe
componenttext: No, that's a great nuance. We had a necessary orchestrator solution recently. But it  -- there are 2 things with it. One is, it requires a significant level of -- if you want professional service or customization from F5 to make the solution work in a specific environment. And 2, it was only consumable when it's past to an ADC. The solution we are now releasing is going to significantly expand the addressable market for F5 in 2 ways. Number one, a lot of the customizations that we build with our customers over the last couple of years is, we've really now productized all these customization and therefore, the consumption motion or the ease of deployment is much greater for our customers. And so we would expect to see a lot more velocity in the deployment of these solutions. number two, we made substantial changes to the solution with things like ease of configuration, not make the solution consumable by security buyer not attached to an ADC. And that allows us to address a new part of the market playing purely with security vendors.

componenttext: Mark, the -- a couple of things. One is, I think we are -- our view is unchanged from what we shared with you in March that our expectation is that in 2019, what we will see 2019 and 2020, we said, we will see lower to mid-single digit growth overall that will most likely be lower in '19 and mid in '20, in part because I would say small decline in the systems business and continued strong growth in the software business. All the indicators we have seen since March tend to validate that, that is, what I think, we will see in 2019. One needs to be careful about taking too much sort of conclusions from a single quarter, because now that we're disclosing our software number, which is still a relatively -- it's only 15% of product revenue so it's still a relatively small number. Quarter-to-quarter, that can be lumpy. We can see a higher software growth quarter and low software growth quarter. But when you look at it on an annual basis, the trends that we have talked are really going to continue.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Hello and good afternoon, everyone. As the operator said, I am Dennis Melton, F5's Interim Lead of Investor Relations. François Locoh-Donou, President and CEO of F5; and Frank Pelzer, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other memb
componenttext:
Hello and good afternoon, everyone. As the operator said, I am Dennis Melton, F5's Interim Lead of Investor Relations. François Locoh-Donou, President and CEO of F5; and Frank Pelzer, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of the F5 Executive team are also on hand to answer questions following the prepared remarks.
If you have any questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6078 or d.melton@f5.com. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at www.f5.com. In addition, you can access an archived version of today's call from our website through October 24, 2018. You can also listen to a telephone replay at (866) 511-5155 or (203) 369-1955. 
In today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words, such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized on our quarterly release and described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call. 
I will now turn the call over to Frank.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dennis. My name is Frank Pelzer, and I'm very excited to discuss with you today our fiscal 2018 Q3 results and Q4 outlook. Q3 marked a return to product revenue growth, as we had another quarter of solid execution and delivery of results. We
componenttext:
Thank you, Dennis. My name is Frank Pelzer, and I'm very excited to discuss with you today our fiscal 2018 Q3 results and Q4 outlook. 
Q3 marked a return to product revenue growth, as we had another quarter of solid execution and delivery of results. We continue to see growing momentum with our software offerings, particularly solutions for multi-cloud architectures, and our services business delivered another quarter of strong revenue and profit. 
Third quarter revenue was $542 million, up 4.7% year-over-year and came in above the midpoint of our guided range of $535 million to $545 million.
GAAP EPS of $1.99 per share was above our guidance of $1.79 to $1.82 per share. This beat was largely driven by strength in revenue, expense discipline and the lower-than-expected effective tax rate. Non-GAAP EPS of $2.44 per share was also above our guidance of $2.36 to $2.39 per share. 
In Q3, product revenue was $239 million, up 1.6% year-over-year and accounted for 44% of total revenue. Software was approximately 15% of product revenue and grew 24% year-over-year. Systems revenue made up approximately 85% of product revenue and declined 1.5% year-over-year.
Services revenue was $303 million, up 7% year-over-year and represented 56% of total revenue. 
On a regional basis, Americas grew 3% year-over-year and represented 56% of total revenue. EMEA revenue grew 8% year-over-year and accounted for 24% of overall revenue. APAC revenue, which accounted for 15% of total, grew 8% year-over-year. And Japan at 4% of total revenue, grew 4% from a year ago. 
Sales to enterprise customers represented 64% of total revenue during the quarter. Service providers accounted for 19% of total revenue, and government sales were 17%, including 7% from U.S. Federal. 
In Q3, we had 5 greater than 10% distributors.
Ingram Micro, which accounted for approximately 17% of total revenue. SYNNEX Corp. and Tech Data, which each accounted for approximately 11%, and Arrow and Westcon each represented approximately 10% of revenue.
I will now discuss our operating results. 
GAAP gross margin in Q3 was 83.2%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 84.5% in line with our expectation. GAAP operating expenses of $299 million were at the lower end of our $297 million to $307 million guided range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $265 million. Our GAAP operating margin in Q3 was 27%, and non-GAAP operating margin was 36%. Our GAAP effective tax rate was 20.4%, lower than expected due to tax benefits associated with our stock-based compensation expense in the quarter. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 23.3%. Let's now discuss the balance sheet and other results.
We generated $182 million in cash flow from operations, up 12% year-over-year, which contributed to cash and investments totaling over $1.4 billion at quarter end. DSO at the end of the quarter was 49 days, flat with previous quarter. Capital expenditures for the quarter were approximately $20 million, driven by our build-out of our new headquarters and international facilities expansion. Inventory at the end of the quarter was approximately $31 million.
Deferred revenue increased 9% year-over-year to just over $1 billion, driven by continued high maintenance renewal rates. We ended the quarter with approximately 4,475 employees, up approximately 90 people from the prior quarter. 
In Q3, we purchased approximately 900,000 shares of our common stock at an average price of $166.22 per share for a total of $150 million. 
Now let me discuss our guidance for Q4. Based on strengthening pipeline and discussion with our sales organization, we see continuing momentum in the business as we close out the fiscal year. We expect to deliver another quarter of solid revenue growth with continued strength in product revenue. 
For the quarter, we are targeting revenue in the range of $555 million to $565 million. Today, we announced an initiative to further align spend with our transformation to a leading provider of multi-cloud application services. Specifically, we will be accelerating investment in our road map and market development efforts in the fastest growing areas of our business, cloud and security. As a result, we expect to take a restructuring charge in the range of $23 million to $25 million in Q4, that is reflected in our GAAP expense estimates.  We do not anticipate that this action will impact our Horizon 1 or Horizon 2 financial guidance that we laid out for you in March. 
In Q4, we expect GAAP gross margins of approximately 83%, including $5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. We anticipate non-GAAP gross margins of approximately 84.5%. We estimate GAAP operating expenses of $317 million to $329 million, including approximately $34 million of stock-based compensation expense, $23 million to $25 million in restructuring expense, and $0.8 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. We expect a GAAP effective tax rate of approximately 25% for the fourth quarter and a non-GAAP effective tax rate at or around 24%. 
Our Q4 GAAP earnings target is $1.77 to $1.80 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $2.61 to $2.64 per share. 
On a final topic, I'm happy to report that my first few months as F5 CFO have gone very smoothly. I've had the opportunity to work with all areas and levels in the business and have been very impressed by the high quality and depth of knowledge of all F5 employees, particularly our world-class finance and accounting team.
I would like to thank everyone for their warm acceptance of me to the organization and their tireless efforts in building a fantastic business. 
With that, I will turn the call over to François.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank, and good afternoon, everyone. During the third quarter, we saw continued momentum across the business with product revenue returning to growth. Software revenue continues to expand driven by deployments in public and private cloud, as
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank, and good afternoon, everyone. 
During the third quarter, we saw continued momentum across the business with product revenue returning to growth. Software revenue continues to expand driven by deployments in public and private cloud, as our customers increasingly look to support and protect their applications across multi-cloud environments. We also saw strong demand for our security solutions, protecting enterprise customers against application-based threats. 
Our software revenue continues to expand, growing 24% year-over-year. The pace of ELA and VE subscription software deals accelerated in Q3, as customers continue to embrace flexible consumption models, a trend we think will be important in driving adoption of our new cloud offerings, including our recently introduced BIG-IP Cloud Edition.
While Cloud Edition was just released to market at the end of May, we are already seeing strong interest and pipeline across the theaters. The early feedback from customers, who purchased the product in Q3, confirms our view that rightsized application services for every app opens up a large set of use cases that were not previously well addressed by existing software ADC offerings. We expect momentum for Cloud Edition to continue to build and that it will be a meaningful driver of software growth in FY '19 and beyond.
In addition, we are seeing our customers increasingly choose to deploy a blend of both iSeries systems along with software in multi-cloud environment. Customers continue to utilize F5 security, application services and orchestration to seamlessly manage workloads across these hybrid environments. 
Our services business had another solid quarter with revenue up 7% year-over-year and deferred revenue of $1 billion. This team provides unparalleled customer support, creating a significant differentiator and driving customer satisfaction. The value of our services capabilities will only grow, as the complexities associated with multi-cloud deployments become more prominent with our customers. 
We've shown strong execution during the third quarter for software solutions across all deployment environments with strength in public cloud, both in bring your own license and utility-based consumption. We also saw a continued sequential growth for enterprise license agreements and subscription offerings. These offerings provide flexibility in procuring and deploying our virtual edition, leading to software expansion in service provider and enterprise accounts.
For instance, our ability to structure an ELA at a large U.S. financial services company help create a high-capacity DNS infrastructure. The policy-based DNS functionality provides resiliency against outages across regional hubs. The deployment works across the 3 major clouds, allowing the customer to choose the right cloud provider for the task at hand. This ELA is part of multi-cloud software infrastructure and the customer continues to buy hardware systems to support a hybrid environment.
The traction we are seeing in software is augmented with the early success of BIG-IP Cloud Edition, which we officially launched on May 31. As a reminder, this release improved per app visibility, analytics and auto scale capabilities. The solution provides app owners a virtual application delivery controller that can apply and automate policy when developing, deploying and securing applications across public and private clouds. 
A large online services company in Asia purchased Cloud Edition to automate application deployment and shorten scale out time. Utilizing BIG-IP functionality paired with Cloud Edition, the customer was able to auto scale instances at the app level with analytics and seamless interoperability with other F5 solutions. 
Application protection continues to be a driver of security solutions with good momentum in our WAF offerings. A leading independent research firm identified F5 as a WAF leader with multiple consumption models, including a traditional application security manager, Advanced Web Application Firewall and Silverline managed service. In the first full quarter of sale, Advanced WAF is showing strong adoption from both new and existing customers. The operational ease of configuration and deployment is attracting new stand-alone security buyers. A great example of this momentum in security is a competitive win at a European web hosting company, driven by our Advanced Web Application Firewall.
The customer deployed Advanced WAF to protect their website portals and safeguard their brand reputation from application-level compromise by sophisticated Layer 7 DDoS attacks. 
The sales team participated in a competitive evaluation and demonstrated protection from bot-based attacks and superior behavior-based protection to catch subtle application layer DDoS attempts.
Highlighting our stated objective of offering stand-alone security products to a security buyer. Today, we are introducing F5 SSL Orchestrator. This dedicated security solution allows ease of deployment and configuration for enterprise customers that demand orchestration with high performance decryption, encryption and steering of SSL traffic. This product gives customers a security appliance, offering dynamic service chaining across the security infrastructure. 
Consistent with our approach presented in our Analyst and Investor Meeting in March, we will continue to expand our stand-alone security portfolio. And today, we also announced the availability of F5 Access Manager. 
Core enhancements include protection of sensitive data with adaptive authentication, while providing access for authorized users, devices and APIs, guarding against pervasive threads, such as man-in-the-middle attacks. Access Manager enables organizations to bridge on-prem app functionality to the cloud, effectively integrating with identity-as-a-service solutions to support evolving, heterogeneous environments.
As we outlined over the past year, we are evolving to a multi-cloud application services company that will reach every app anywhere. With this in mind, we are realigning resources to better position F5 for 2019 and beyond. 
Today, we are taking steps to notify some employees that their roles are under consideration or will be eliminated in order to accelerate our hiring in geographic sales expansion, new sales go-to-market motions, multi-cloud software development and digital transformation initiatives. 
Our objective with these decisions is to further align our workforce with a long-term strategy and accelerate the transformation that we outlined in our Analyst and Investor Meeting earlier this year.
The long-term vision set forth is seeing significant traction with continued momentum in software and security sales. Customers continue to view our solutions as mission-critical in hybrid environments and they deploy incremental workloads dynamically, both on-premise and in cloud environments. The expansion of our software asset portfolio and stand-alone security products positions us as the leader in multi-cloud application services.
Before moving on to the question-and-answer session, I wanted to highlight 3 key additions to the leadership team. First, I am excited to announce that Chad Whalen has been promoted to Executive Vice President of Worldwide Sales. Chad joined F5 18 months ago, and has built up our cloud sales team, while significantly deepening our partnerships with Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services. Chad also brought to F5 a depth of experience that spans complex, large enterprises to fast-moving startups. His past leadership roles included Fortinet, World Wide Packets, Jasper and Ciena. Chad brings a combination of cloud, security, IoT and service provider expertise that we will leverage in our transformation to become a multi-cloud application services leader.
We were also pleased to announce on July 11, that Mary Gardner joined the F5 team as our new Chief Information Security Officer. Mary is a seasoned security leader with extensive experience in the health and finance sectors, where the protection of highly sensitive customer data and compliance with stringent regulations are business-critical issues. 
Prior to F5, Mary has held security leadership roles at Seattle Children's Hospital, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center and kept information and networks safe at Port of Seattle and Washington Mutual, JPMorgan Chase. 
Another important addition to our leadership team is James Feger, who joined this month as General Manager for our service provider business. James comes to us after 14 years at CenturyLink, where he held multiple leadership roles supporting the design and operations of their network architecture, including his most recent role as Vice President of Network Virtualization.
His hands-on insight into the challenges and opportunities service providers face as they rollout 5G, NFV and IoT services will be invaluable to F5 as we expand our reach and role in these environments. 
I would like to welcome Chad, Mary and James to their roles on the F5 leadership team. 
As always, I would like to thank the entire F5 team and our partners for their efforts during the third quarter. 
With that, we will now hand the call over for Q&A.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018

componenttextpreview: I just wanted to start off with a question on the restructuring that you announced today. How should I think about the payback on that kind of restructuring. Is it sort of -- the intention here is to sort of improve margins on the systems product? Or how
componenttext: I just wanted to start off with a question on the restructuring that you announced today. How should I think about the payback on that kind of restructuring. Is it sort of -- the intention here is to sort of improve margins on the systems product? Or how should I think about impact on the financials longer-term?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Samik. Well, the first thing I'd say about the restructuring is that, I genuinely don't like having to make these decisions, because ideally and philosophically, we would like to embark every employee that's been part of this journey with F5 in
componenttext: Thank you, Samik. Well, the first thing I'd say about the restructuring is that, I genuinely don't like having to make these decisions, because ideally and philosophically, we would like to embark every employee that's been part of this journey with F5 into this exciting future that we're building with the company. And the Executive team has taken immense consideration on this because we know that we are making decisions that impact the lives of many of our colleagues and friends. That being said, we are very focused on the transformation of F5 into a multi-cloud application services leader. And as a result, there is legacy spend that we have that is less relevant to the future than it has been for the past. And we are shifting our focus to the growth areas of F5. And specifically, we are intensifying our investments into software and multi-cloud technologies, in new go-to-market motions and also in building the necessary digital infrastructure that enables those go-to-market motions. And so today's restructuring is really not about cost cutting, it really is about real realignment of resources towards these areas and accelerating the execution of our strategy. In terms of how you should think about this action as it relates to long-term financial model, it's all very consistent with what we shared at our Analyst and Investor Meeting in March, and so this action has no implied change in our Horizon 1 and Horizon 2 guidance, so this is FY '19 and also '21, '22.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. That's helpful. And then just a follow-up, you mentioned that you're seeing good traction on your stand-alone security product. Can you maybe share any kind of metrics in terms of either customer count or anything like that so that we can
componenttext: Got it, got it. That's helpful. And then just a follow-up, you mentioned that you're seeing good traction on your stand-alone security product. Can you maybe share any kind of metrics in terms of either customer count or anything like that so that we can track your progress on that front? And also, are your latest thoughts that you can sort of pursue that opportunity organically, or are you open to sort of looking at maybe acquisitions of bolt-on acquisitions to bolster your -- keep the lead on that front?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Samik, I'll start with the latter part of your question. In terms of acquisitions, I think we've touched on this before. I've said that, I consider acquisitions to be a potential tool in the execution of our strategy as a technology company. If and when w
componenttext: Samik, I'll start with the latter part of your question. In terms of acquisitions, I think we've touched on this before. I've said that, I consider acquisitions to be a potential tool in the execution of our strategy as a technology company. If and when we find that there's an opportunity that makes sense, we will execute on that. And the key for me is that we continue to be disciplined in our investments, whether they be investments in organic innovation or potential investments in inorganic innovation in the future that we've taken a very disciplined approach to both and that's what you're seeing in our actions today. In terms of the tractions that we're getting with our new stand-alone security offerings, we don't disclose customer accounts, but I can tell you that the new stand-alone security solutions that we have announced, we have already won number of customers with, including a number of customers that are net new customers to F5. And the thing that is for me a significant sign of the traction we're getting there is in a number of these deals we're winning with our SSL orchestration solutions or our Advanced WAF solutions. We are not competing with any ADC vendors. We're really only competing with traditional or next-generation security vendors. And our win rate is very strong. A good example of that is, if you take our SSL orchestration solution, we just released, it really is a use case that is absolutely critical to the security infrastructure, largely because most of the traffic now is encrypted. And so the traditional security appliances are not very efficient at doing this encryption, decryption work in addition to the security service they have to offer. And so in this case, actually, F5's hardware -- security hardware is extremely efficient than encryption and decryption and we marry that with an intelligent policy-based chaining of security services. And that allows us to provide a service chain across the full security stack and really nobody else can do that. So that's just a great use case for how our stand-alone security solutions are performing. And it is absolutely in line with our strategy to be the leader in application security.

componenttext: I was hoping if you could give us maybe potentially an attach rate of the software and security revenues, just specifically hardware sales in the quarter. headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sami, I don't think we can give you an attach rate specifically. What I think, we can -- I think, share with you is, 2 things. One is, you continue to see growth in our software, essentially in line with what we shared at the Investor meeting, that softwa
componenttext: Sami, I don't think we can give you an attach rate specifically. What I think, we can -- I think, share with you is, 2 things. One is, you continue to see growth in our software, essentially in line with what we shared at the Investor meeting, that software would grow in the mid-20s for the year. And we're confident this is essentially where we're going to land. And that's true across both our software growth in ADC and our software growth in security. And I think that is -- that has been the consistent trend over the number of quarters. The other thing we can share with you is, a large number of deals, even in security, I would say, a growing percentage of our business even in ADC, sorry, is actually driven by security use cases. So we don't break down and we don't quantify that, but I'd say, the traction in security is growing both in our ADC business as well as in our stand-alone security business.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then at the Analyst Day, there were some comments alluding to an as-a-service product and the business model shift, et cetera. And I was hoping you kind of give us a little bit of an update around that and maybe any potential milestones or may
componenttext: Got it. And then at the Analyst Day, there were some comments alluding to an as-a-service product and the business model shift, et cetera. And I was hoping you kind of give us a little bit of an update around that and maybe any potential milestones or maybe just like a change of mind or anything like that, can you just give us some color on that?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we -- Sami, we offer today a managed service where we essentially redirect traffic from some of our customers to scrubbing centers that are largely in Equinix data centers. And then we perform a number of services in these scrubbing centers and th
componenttext: Yes, so we -- Sami, we offer today a managed service where we essentially redirect traffic from some of our customers to scrubbing centers that are largely in Equinix data centers. And then we perform a number of services in these scrubbing centers and that matter shows you the Silverline and it continues to grow with other number of customers they get in the quarter. In addition to that, we did say that in 2019, we would be bringing to market a solution we'd called, F5-as-a-service, which is a -- it's a complete self-serve model that would be hosted in a public cloud, and would address all of the DevOps buyers that want to go through a pure public cloud buying motion. We remain on track for that solution in 2019. We haven't announced the date yet and we will, as we get closer to delivering on that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018

componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Henderson from Needham.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Great. I was wondering if you could just give us some qualified sizing around the growth rate in the security business. I know you don't want to break out the dollar value of it, but it would be helpful if you could at least talk about roughly what the ra
componenttext: Great. I was wondering if you could just give us some qualified sizing around the growth rate in the security business. I know you don't want to break out the dollar value of it, but it would be helpful if you could at least talk about roughly what the rate of change in that business is. And then the second, if you could talk a little bit about what portion of your business is coming from SaaS or cloud-related footprint, that would be helpful as well.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Alex, thank you. I'm going to disappoint you on both counts. Because I can't give you numericals. And it's not just that we want, but let me start with security. In security, our business is both some stand-alone security use cases as well as security-dri
componenttext: Alex, thank you. I'm going to disappoint you on both counts. Because I can't give you numericals. And it's not just that we want, but let me start with security. In security, our business is both some stand-alone security use cases as well as security-driven use cases in our ADC business. And sometimes breaking that up is actually quite subjective on our part. And this is one of the reasons that we don't disclose that information. I can, on the other hand, share with you that security as a whole is a, one of the faster growing areas of our business. So it is growing faster than the aggregate revenue, if you will. As it relates to public cloud, again, we don't -- today, we may in the future. But we don't today, purely breakout public cloud revenues. Public cloud is actually the fastest-growing part of our business. And we continue to drive customers to public clouds both buy their license and instant sharing it in the public cloud or buying into our systems on the utility basis. I'm sure that we're now building millions of hours per quarter in the -- on all the major public clouds. And our Cloud Edition that we've just released, actually, we expect to accelerate that, because it makes it easy for customers to burst some of their applications into a public cloud, leveraging our auto scale capabilities. And so that's where we see significant acceleration of our software solutions in the future. But I just can't quantify it for you yet.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. Could I follow up though, you last quarter given positive comments on both your million dollars deals as well as, I think, the term you used was accelerating pipeline of deals that you were chasing. Can you at least qualify something around that, is
componenttext: Okay. Could I follow up though, you last quarter given positive comments on both your million dollars deals as well as, I think, the term you used was accelerating pipeline of deals that you were chasing. Can you at least qualify something around that, is there any change or is there any reason why you didn't mention that this time around?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: No, there is no reason. We didn't mention it, Alex. We saw -- as we kind of predicted last quarter, we saw growing number of 7-figure software deals. And these are typically ELAs, enterprise license agreements, and we're seeing -- we only released these o
componenttext: No, there is no reason. We didn't mention it, Alex. We saw -- as we kind of predicted last quarter, we saw growing number of 7-figure software deals. And these are typically ELAs, enterprise license agreements, and we're seeing -- we only released these offerings about 9 months ago. And sequentially, every quarter over the last 3 quarters, we have seen the traction in pipeline with this consumption model growing with our customers. And this quarter, we had a record number of such deals on software and on these enterprise license agreements. They are particularly important to us, because we can land customers on these deals and over time expand them as they add to their initial subscription. So generally, pretty excited about what's happening with the large million-dollars-plus software deals that we are seeing.

componenttext: So that's a strong number in the quarter and strong pipeline, just to be sure, is that right?

componenttext: Correct.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rod from Goldman Sachs.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to -- I guess, I want to ask a kind of a question about the progress of software again, but the real question I have is, when you guys think you might release some KPIs that would help us quantify those, so that we can understand either maybe wha
componenttext: I wanted to -- I guess, I want to ask a kind of a question about the progress of software again, but the real question I have is, when you guys think you might release some KPIs that would help us quantify those, so that we can understand either maybe what proportion of product revenue the software sales are, or some other KPI that you've got in mind that would help us track actual quantifiable progress on that strategy. So that's, I guess, one question. Another one is related to that, which is deferred revenue, which was flat quarter-on-quarter. And I guess, we expect the software products to be pretty small at this point. But that deferred revenue suggests there's not a whole lot of movement in the direction of software yet from the point of view of the overall revenue. So I'm just curious, is that true? Or is there a bunch of some more software deferred revenue in there than we think? And if we could see the breakdown, we would see more progress.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. Rod, it's Frank. Let me take that one. So on the KPI question, I would say, as the business becomes more material, we'll consider certain KPIs that you can continue to track. At this point, we're talking about the growth rates that we've experienced
componenttext: Sure. Rod, it's Frank. Let me take that one. So on the KPI question, I would say, as the business becomes more material, we'll consider certain KPIs that you can continue to track. At this point, we're talking about the growth rates that we've experienced in the business, particularly on the software side as an indication of the strength that we're seeing in that business. I think on your second question, on the deferred revenue. It was actually up and close to 7%, 1.7% quarter-over-quarter, but 7% year-over-year. And we talked about that's really still the continued strength that we've seen in the maintenance. On the ELA side, and those are just a smaller portion of our total revenue. And so it really has -- doesn't have a major move yet in the deferred revenue piece.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. Frank, can I follow up, I just -- the other thing we noticed is APAC and Japan, the Japanese decline was lower, APAC growth is better. Just curious, if you guys have any further color on what drove those continued changes in trajectory there, it see
componenttext: Okay. Frank, can I follow up, I just -- the other thing we noticed is APAC and Japan, the Japanese decline was lower, APAC growth is better. Just curious, if you guys have any further color on what drove those continued changes in trajectory there, it seems like things are improving.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think it's positive market dynamics, particularly in some emerging economies that we haven't necessarily had as much presence in before, particularly China and India. And so we were really excited to report that kind of growth. And I think we've got a r
componenttext: I think it's positive market dynamics, particularly in some emerging economies that we haven't necessarily had as much presence in before, particularly China and India. And so we were really excited to report that kind of growth. And I think we've got a really strong team that's executing quite well.
